awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Nebraska, located in Lincoln, Nebraska, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks, during the summers of 2016- 2019. The program focuses on bioenergy -- the application of molecular and physiologic principles using microbes, algae and plants to create renewable sources of energy to promote a sustainable society. The School of Biological Sciences and the Center for Plant Science Innovation have 15 participating faculty who will serve as mentors. There are many exciting and interdisciplinary projects available for students that employ biotechnology, molecular biology, and biochemistry and/or genetics to understand energy dynamics in model species. In addition to full time research, students will participate in seminars and various workshops about research ethics, professionalism, career opportunities in industry and academia, and the graduate school application process. Additional features include tours of energy industries and training in technical writing using a collaborative and student-centered approach. REU students have access to a Carnegie I-ranked research institution with all its infrastructure and diversity.  

It is anticipated that a total of 40 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. The program?s multi-phase recruitment effort consists of traditional "hard copy" formats, digital-based advertising, and networking with faculty at diverse institutions, including community colleges. Students are selected based on their academic record as well as their interest and potential in research Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of their research experience. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences), along with institutional tools, will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine student career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.unl.edu/summerprogram/research#bioenergy, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Paul Blum at pblum1@unl.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Heriberto Cerutti at hcerutti1@unl.edu).

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
From 2016-?2019, University of Nebraska?Lincoln (UNL) microbiologists and plant biologists continued a highly successful NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in the ?Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems?. The primary goals were to teach science to undergraduate students through active learning approaches and to encourage career decisions towards socially relevant scientific research.

 One of the greatest challenges facing 21st?century society is finding a sustainable energy supply. Energy is the basis for a large portion of the global economy and, currently, we are primarily dependent on nonrenewable fossil fuels. Not only are reserves dwindling, but the use of nonrenewable fossil fuels also contributes significantly to pollution and climate change. Biomass from plants, algae and cyanobacteria represents an abundant carbon?neutral renewable resource for the production of energy and biomaterials. Microbes offer efficient and sustainable ways to convert this biomass into liquid fuels or chemical feedstock. With adequate research and proper implementation, plants, algae, and other microorganisms have great potential to help address the energy crisis. To make this sustainable energy reality, however, there is a crucial need to train a new generation of scientists in bioenergy systems.

 The Microbiology Initiative (MBI) and the Center for Plant Science Innovation (CPSI) are interdisciplinary programs at the University of Nebraska?Lincoln charged with promoting innovative research that crosses traditional departmental boundaries. Together they have over 50 faculty members and over 150 graduate students undergoing training in bacteriology, archaea, virology, plant pathology, biology, biochemistry, biotechnology, chemical engineering, bioinformatics, genetics food science, agronomy, and molecular plant sciences. Both MBI and CPSI have received UNL University Program of Excellence (PoE) funds to foster innovative ways to develop, grow, and promote interdisciplinary research and training. A common theme inherent to these strong faculty clusters is the development of biological systems for energy production.

KEY OUTCOMES:

NSF funding allowed this program to over highly specialized training to 40 undergraduate students originating from diverse institutions across the United States. These students were selected from over 900 qualified applicants. All of the students completed the program requirements consisting of 10 weeks of laboratory training in bioenergy research, public scientific presentations of their work, and participation in seminars and workshops on ethics, professionalism, and STEM careers.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/10/2022
Modified by: Paul H Blum

    Bioenergy REU Students
